Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Modeling Communication Management and Trust Networks in Ebola Response in the Dallas-Fort Worth Metropolitan Region

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The general aim of this Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) is to collect ephemeral data of ad hoc collaborations developing and dissolving in response to Ebola. Capturing the nature of collaboration and information exchanged can assist in designing a crisis communication system that will help local government organizations be better prepared for surprise events. The project activities will also advance the state of knowledge of how city governance and emergency response organizations receive and communicate risk information to solve protective action dilemmas, especially during a pandemic outbreak. The findings will be shared with the first responders in the region. This will in turn impact a larger population of over 6.4 million citizens who reside in the Dallas-Fort Worth (DFW) region. In addition to advancing undergraduate and graduate teaching, training, and learning, the study provides a doctoral student with field research, data collection, coding, analysis, and publication experience. By leveraging the knowledge of a large network of alumni from the Master of Public Administration and the Emergency Administration and Planning programs, will also meet the university's goals of being a regional leader in research and contributing to solving societal problems.

Based on the Institutional Collective Action framework, the first objective is to investigate the ad hoc communication and trust networks that have emerged in responding to Ebola between city managers, first responders, and key health care personnel in the DFW region. Currently, there are no studies of Ebola response at the organizational level. Previous scholars generally used public sources to map terrorist organizations networks; others employed content analysis of official documents detailing preparedness planning to map the type/patterns of interorganizational collaboration, and described such interactions and collaborations as metaphors. However, such techniques of data collection and analysis are fraught with limitations due to incomplete information and biases in media framing and reporting. The meaningful benefits of ad hoc collaborations to individual organizations are also seldom noted by the mass media. Using Social Network Analysis, we seek to investigate whether closely-knitted community organizations with a strong sense of belongingness can enhance the capacity of individual organizations to gain access to a wide range of additional information. The second objective is to examine the "outcome" related to risk communication and protective action decision-making of these network structures. The data collection will be conducted through 40 face-to-face semi-structured interviews of emergency management coordinators followed by mail surveys of 300-350 emergency response agencies. This study will result in at least two peer-reviewed publications, three presentations at the Natural Hazards and Application Workshop, the American Society for Public Administration, and at Regional Emergency Managers and Voluntary Organizations Active in Disasters (VOAD) meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this research were to examine the ad hoc collaborations that developed and dissolved in response to the Ebola crisis in the Dallas Fort Worth (DFW) Metropolitan region in the USA.  Specifically, the first objective was to investigate how response organizations communicated and led their jurisdictions in the first month following the confirmation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) that Mr. Eric Duncan ---a Liberian national visiting Dallas, Texas had tested positive for Ebola; and his subsequent death on October 8th, 2014.  The second objective was to identify challenges and subsequent changes implemented to Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for infectious diseases, by responding agencies in the metropolitan region and implications for practice.

The research team conducted 24 semi-structured interviews in summer 2015 with key informants from health departments and emergency management departments in cities, counties, hospitals and universities in the DFW area, and a follow up e-survey with 28 respondents.  Social Network Analysis (SNA) was applied to first identify responding organizations that had strong pre-existing ‘bonding networks’ characterized by a sense of close-knit belongingness among community organizations that facilitated sharing of information and pooling of resources. Second, SNA helped identify organizations that demonstrated the capacity for strong ‘bridging networks’ characterized by their ability to serve as leaders by occupying a central position in accessing information, novel resources, and effectively coordinating activities of other response organizations in the metroplex.

Findings from the SNA suggest that the CDC, the Texas Department of State Health Services, City of Dallas Office of Emergency Management, the Dallas County Office of Homeland Security and Emergency Management, and county governments in the region emerged as organizations with the highest bridging and bonding scores.  While these patterns of collaborations using statistical analyses demonstrate their ability to serve as sources of risk information, there is a need for caution in interpreting the results. Textual analyses of open-ended responses from key informants including emergency management personnel from smaller adjoining cities indicated feelings of frustration at the aforementioned organizations for not promptly sharing the list of individuals being monitored for Ebola across DFW in the first few weeks. This led smaller cities to depend on longstanding friendship networks for up to date information. There was also  consensus that first responder agencies like the police, fire and emergency medical services were also at a major disadvantage because of the changing directives from the CDC regarding the use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) for response and training for infectious diseases like Ebola.

In the months following the crisis, the Governor of Texas instituted the HB2646 Bill amending the Texas Health and Safety Code. There is now a clause which authorizes the disclosure of information by local health departments for infectious disease threats allowing first responders access to individuals being monitored for communicable diseases through the EMS dispatch system.  Furthermore, the aftermath of the Ebola crisis in the region has seen many response agencies creating or amending existing SOPs in preparation for future infectious disease threats. Special inclusions include protocols for donning and doffing PPEs, sharing of information with first responder agencies, fitting ambulance for transportation of infected patients and plans for regular drills and exercises to test their plans.

In conclusion, this research advances the state of knowledge on the nature of intergovernmental collaborations by applying the SNA to understand how organizations solved emergency response dilemmas during the Ebola crisis. The research findings have been shared at four professional meetings in the areas of disaster management and public administration. In addition to advancing undergraduate and graduate teaching, training, and learning, this project enabled two doctoral students to gain valuable experiences related to data collection, content analysis of official documents, quantitative social networks analysis, report writing, making presentations and working on manuscripts for publication.
